metadata.title: Behavior, remediation effect and toxicity of nanomaterials in water environments

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect

Review article
Behavior, remediation effect and toxicity of nanomaterials in water environments
Yi Zhua,1, Xianli Liua,1, Yali Hua, Rui Wanga, Ming Chenb,∗, Jianhua Wuc, Yanyan Wangd, Shuang Kangb, Yan Sunb, Mengxi Zhub
a School of Environmental Science & Engineering, Hubei Polytechnic University, Huangshi 435003, PR China b College of Environmental Science and Engineering, Hunan University and Key Laboratory of Environmental Biology and Pollution Control (Hunan University), Ministry of Education, Changsha, 410082, PR China c School of Resources and Environmental Engineering, Wuhan University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, 430080, PR China d School of Land Resources and Environment, Jiangxi Agricultural University, Nanchang, 330045, PR China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Nanomaterials Water environment Remediation Toxicity
A B S T R A C T
In recent years, nanotechnology has been developing continuously. Due to their advantageous huge specific surface areas, microinterface characteristics, remediation ability and potential environmental risks, nanomaterials have become a hot topic in the field of environmental research. With the mass production and use of nanomaterials, they will inevitably be discharged or leaked into the water environment. In this paper, we will describe some typical nanomaterials, such as nanoscale zero valent iron (nZVI), graphene nanomaterials (GNMs), TiO2 nanoparticles (NPs), ZnO NPs, Fe3O4 NPs, carbon nanotubes (CNTs), Ag NPs, and other nanomaterials in water environments, focusing on the positive and negative effects of some nanomaterials in water environments. The remediation function and the impact of nanomaterials in water environments, including behavior of nanomaterials and their toxicity to aquatic organisms will be discussed. This will be of great significance for our subsequent research on nanomaterials.

sections.heading: 1. Environmental behavior of nanomaterials in water environment
sections.text:
Currently, most scientists believe that nanomaterials are one of the mainstays of developing science and technology in the 21st century. A growing number of nanomaterials can enter the environment (Adam and Nowack, 2017; Caballero-Guzman and Nowack, 2016), especially the water environment, through different pathways. Therefore, the relationship between nanomaterials and water environments has become a hot topic worldwide. The behavior of nanomaterials in various water environments including lake, river, ocean, and wetlands has been investigated in the past years. Next we will elaborate the relationship between nanomaterials and water environment (Fig. 1).
In the lake environment, nanomaterials can affect microbial activity and growth. Simultaneously, the properties and behavior of nanomaterials may be influenced by lakes. For example, the stability of Ag NPs coated with polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP), citrate (CIT), or lipoic acid (LIP) at different sizes in lake water was examined, and results showed that AgNPs stability was determined by dissolved organic matter
(DOM), exposure time and the surface coating characteristics (Jimenez−Lamana and Slaveykova, 2016). The study further found that surface coating was a key factor governing the behavior of AgNPs in lake water. The impact of titanium nanoparticles (TiO2 NPs) on freshwater bacteria in three Swedish lakes was studied (Farkas et al., 2015), and the authors found that TiO2 NPs could inhibit the proliferation and activity of bacteria in the lakes.
The increase of nanomaterials in rivers comes from various potential artificial channels, such as nanotechnology waste, oil refinery, automobile traffic, life drain, vessel, etc. For instance, environmental concentrations of fullerenes and their derivatives in Sava River have been determined (Sanchís et al., 2018). C60 was found to be the most common fullerene. If its concentration is in the range of 8 pg/L-59 ng/L in water, C60 will not cause significant toxicity in water environments. However, the concentrations reported were apparently higher than normal concentrations found in surface water. The key for the increase in content of C60 and its derivatives is that we should pay attention to hydrological conditions.

have studied the behavior of nanomaterials in ocean. A previous study investigated the toxic effect of TiO2 NPs using chlorella as an example of marine organisms (Xia et al., 2018). Results showed that TiO2 NPs could clearly increase the oxidative damage of algal cells, because OA may result in higher aggregation degree of NPs and acute environmental problems. Under the influence of long-term OA, compared to the blank control, the presence of zinc oxide nanoparticles enhances the activity of some mussel enzymes, such as acid phosphatase (ACP), superoxide dismutase (SOD), catalase (CAT), alkaline phosphatase (ALP), and glutathione peroxidase (GPx) (Huang et al., 2018a). Therefore, under the current conditions of OA, some nanomaterials (e.g., TiO2 NPs) may cause harm to marine organisms, and some nanomaterials (e.g., ZnO NPs) may provide benefits to marine organisms.
Artificial wetlands (CWs) are specifically designed to control water pollution, and many scientists have explored the relationship between CWs and different nanoparticles. In ecosystems, the impact of nanoparticles on wastewater is uncertain. It was found that in CWs, TiO2 NPs had no significant impact on the treatment of pollutants in a short term (Yang et al., 2018), but long-term exposure to TiO2 NPs significantly reduced the amount of nitrogen removal in CWs. In addition, long-term binding of CWs to TiO2 NPs would significantly change the performance of microorganisms and plants in CWs. The massive release of nanoparticles will lead to an increase in their environmental risks (Hu et al., 2018). The majority of cerium oxide (CeO2) NPs stays in the substrate of CWs and only a small quantity of CeO2 NPs accumulate in plant tissue cells. In addition, researchers (Cao et al., 2018) studied the influence of Ag NPs on elements in CWs and found that Ag NPs had no significant effect on organic pollution, but they could reduce the removal efficiency of nitrogen (N) and phosphorus (P) in organisms.
Clearly, nanomaterials exhibit various behaviors in water environments, where some nanomaterials showed good potential for water pollution remediation.

sections.heading: 2. Remediation effect and mechanism of nanomaterials in water environment
sections.text:
To establish an environment-friendly economy, it has become a common concern of environmental research institutions at home and abroad to seek environment-friendly remediation agents for the restoration of polluted water bodies and soil (Ye et al., 2017a, 2017b, 2019). Traditional treatment methods of heavy metals and organic dyes from wastewater include activated carbon adsorption, membrane filtration or chlorination, ozonation, ultraviolet radiation and potassium permanganate oxidation. Activated carbon adsorption is one of the main methods for treating industrial wastewater on a secondary or tertiary level. Activated carbon can easily adsorb benzene and petroleum products in water. However, the adsorption effect of activated carbon is effective for a short period of time, and the effect becomes significantly worse after one or two months. After three or four months
activated carbon is basically no longer working. Therefore, it is necessary to find new materials or technologies to address this problem. Currently, nanomaterials are often used for the treatment of sewage, and nanophotocatalytic technology is also often used to oxidize various organic compounds in water by forming OH− ions and superoxide ions with high activity and strong oxidation. There are also nanofiltration membrane technologies that use pressure-driven membranes to separate substances in sewage. In addition, some nanomaterials have an apparent adsorption effect on metal ions or organics due to the hydroxyl groups, which exists on the surface of nanoparticles, binding to certain cations. Carbon NPs, for example, compared with traditional sewage treatment reagents, show higher stability in an acidic or alkaline environment and exhibit a large specific surface area, porous structure, and specific binding sites. Accordingly, the use of nanomaterials to treat wastewater not only overcomes the deficiency of traditional technology but also shows outstanding remediation efficiency.
Nanomaterials such as nanoscale zero valent iron (nZVI), graphene nanomaterials (GNMs), Ag NPs, nanofiltration membrane materials, and nanofiber materials are very useful materials for water pollution remediation. The common preparation methods, working principles and pollution remediation of these nanomaterials are summarized in
Table 1.

sections.heading: 2.1. Shell nuclear - type nZVI
sections.text:
The nZVI particles, with sizes of less than 20 nm, are mainly used to treat a wide range of water pollutants, such as organic chlorinated substances from groundwater, heavy metals and aromatic chlorinated substances from industrial wastewater, adsorbed nitro-aromatic compounds, and azo dyes.
The nZVI particles were added into Hg(II) solution at a concentration of 40mg/L, and removed 98% Hg(II) ions after 2min (Yan et al., 2010). Such a removal speed was quite fast for the removal of heavy metals in water treatment. Therefore, nZVI is also considered to be one of the most promising reagents for rapid environmental cleaning and has become a research hotspot in the field of water restoration. The nZVI particles have a classic core-shell structure consisting of a nonmetallic oxide shell in several nanometers thick enclosing a metal iron core. The iron core is an electron source with reduction characteristics. The thin iron oxide shell, through electrostatic interaction and surface complexation, can promote the adsorption of pollutants. After the nuclear reaction in water and oxygen oxidation, metallic iron is consumed, and nZVI is mainly converted into C—FeOOH mixed with a small amount of Fe3O4 and C—Fe2O3. The iron ions spread outwards, forming an iron oxide shell, which gradually collapses and becomes a flake or acicular structure. Therefore, nZVI has the disadvantage of being easily oxidized, resulting in poor adsorption efficiency in sewage. Further study is thus needed to overcome the deficiency.
At present, borohydride reduction method is used to prepare nZVI
(Liu et al., 2015). The nZVI particles can not only be a potential absorbent for wastewater, but they can also be used as a carrier. Researchers have successfully used nZVI as a carrier to develop sodium alginate (Zhao et al., 2018). As CWs do not have an electron donor, this compound is a new type of electron donor/receptor that can greatly enhance the denitrification effect of CWs. It was found that azollaNaOH is a good stabilizer for the storage of nZVI, and that nZVI has the potential to adsorb and recover Pb(II) and Hg(II) from water even if it has been stored for 6 months in laboratory conditions (Arshadi et al., 2017). Therefore, nZVI is a promising material for water treatment.

sections.heading: 2.2. Graphene nanomaterials (GNMs)
sections.text: Graphene is a single layer of graphite at a nanoscale, and it has promising potential in environmental protection applications. More and more researchers have used GNMs for water environmental governance. The common methods of preparing graphene include mechanical peeling, chemical oxidation-reduction and carbon nanotube conversion. Currently, surfactant pollution is a serious public environmental problem in the aquatic environment. Due to their surface activity characteristics, surfactants can easily diffuse in the water environment and lead to water eutrophication. Graphene oxide (GO) and reduced GO have been used for the adsorption of a nonionic surfactant (TX-100) (Prediger et al., 2018). The results showed that GO and rGO had the highest adsorption capacity for TX-100 among analyzed materials. It was found that GO had a negative effect on anaerobic denitrification but showed a positive effect on anaerobic ammonia (Suárez−Iglesias et al., 2017). Antibiotic pollution also presents a serious threat to water quality. Antibiotics have various potential toxicity possibilities that can be harmful to aquatic organisms, and the traditional wastewater treatment technology has no effects on the removal of some antibiotics. The electrostatic effect can lead to stronger adsorption of tetracycline to GNMs (Zheng et al., 2018). For example, graphene and carbon nanotubes, two common carbon nanomaterials, are effective adsorbents for the removal of tetracycline. rGO was prepared by a photocatalytic reduction method (Zdarta et al., 2018), and rGO/G-C3N4 hybrid film was prepared by vacuum filtration and weak UV irradiation. This film has a high rejection reaction against several salt ions such as sodium ions in a certain amount of water, and therefore graphene functional film has the potential to become the next generation separation film. All the abovementioned results showed that GNMs are promising materials for water pollution remediation. Noteworthy, GNMs may also transform in the environment, changing their ability to adsorb toxic pollutants. It has been demonstrated that black Fe(II) can be used as an environmental friendly mild reducing agent of GNMs (Qu et al., 2016), which can significantly improve the performance of GNMs and stabilize their chemical properties in water.

sections.heading: 2.3. TiO2 NPs
sections.text:
TiO2 NPs have unique photocatalytic properties such as acid and alkali resistance, photochemical corrosion, and nontoxic characteristics, which make them the most promising photocatalyst. Under the action of light, TiO2 NPs can be activated and generate free radicals with high catalytic activity, which can produce strong photooxidation and reduction ability and catalyze the photodecomposition of various organic substances such as formaldehyde and some inorganic substances. Therefore, studies on the application of TiO2 NPs in wastewater treatment are of great positive significance to water environment management.
Taking textile mills as an example, most chemicals in textile mills cannot be degraded when they enter the water, which will seriously pollute the aquatic ecosystem and damage the health of the water environment. Fortunately, it was reported that TiO2 semiconductor photocatalyst can degrade some of these chemicals such as dye in water (Laishram et al., 2018). TiO2 NPs combined with carbon materials had higher photocatalytic activity, solar radiation activity and are easy to separate. Another study also proved that Ag-@TiO2 nanotubes had stronger photocatalytic activity than bare TiO2 NPs (Wang et al., 2017). On the basis of water/oil phase separation, Ag-@TiO2 composite nanotubes were prepared by the method of electrospinning with a large number of active sites on the surface, which could enhance the photocatalytic performance. In addition, natural organic matter (NOM) and disinfection byproducts (DBP) may be detected in drinking water. It was found that TiO2 NPs could be used as an adsorbent to remove NOM and DBP from drinking water (Gora and Andrews, 2017), and experimental data showed that pH affected the removal of NOM from surface water by TiO2 NPs. A concern for using nanomaterials is that adding Pcontaining materials into nanomaterials as additives may cause environment problems (Liu et al., 2013). A study (Olabarrieta et al., 2018) investigated this problem using TiO2 NPs as an example. They successfully separated phosphorus ions from water by low-pressure membrane filtration, which was also an important guarantee for the safe use of nanomaterials in the future.

sections.heading: 2.4. ZnO NPs
sections.text:
ZnO NPs is a high-end, high-performance fine inorganic product that can be applied in many fields such as ceramics, chemicals, electronics, optics, biology, medicine, etc. In addition, ZnO NPs can also be a water body repair material. For example, some scholars have found that ZnO NPs are synthesized from Cordyceps militaris by coprecipitation. Under the condition of ultraviolet radiation, the ZnO NPs have the ability to reduce the harmful dye methylene blue by about 97%(Li et al., 2019b). Compared with a single ZnO NPs, ZnO NPs decorated with other materials can improve the water purification ability of ZnO NPs. The aminosilicate sol-gel-loaded silver NPs (TPDT/(ZnOeAg) NCMs) were obtained by a certain preparation method to decorate the ZnO NPs. The photocatalytic ability of the TPDT/(ZnOeAg) NCMs was investigated under visible light irradiation based on toxic methylene blue (MB) dye and hexavalent chromium (Cr (VI)), respectively. It was found that MB dye was completely decolorized on TPDT/(ZnOeAg) NCMs photocatalyst compared to the controlled photocatalyst material. TPDT/(ZnOeAg) NCM shows better environmental remediation and water purification processes (Praveen et al., 2018).
In addition, the modified particles obtained by synthesizing ZnO NPs with other substances also have antibacterial properties. The nanoZnO-cation polyelectrolyte diallyldimethylammonium chloride (PDDA) modified red mudgranule material obtained by certain experimental methods has significant antibacterial activity against Escherichia coli(Li et al., 2019a).
Although ZnO NPs have such a positive effect on water environment restoration, there is one point that cannot be ignored, that is the toxicity of ZnO NPs. Studies have shown that the survival time of mussels in the presence of ZnO is shorter than that in the absence of ZnO in fresh water or sea water(Gagne et al., 2019)。How to maximize the remediation effect and minimize the toxic effect of ZnO NPs is what we have been trying to explore.

sections.heading: 2.5. Carbon nanotubes (CNTs)
sections.text:
As a one-dimensional nanomaterial, CNTs are light in weight, and have many abnormal mechanical, electrical and chemical properties (Chen et al., 2018; Kang et al., 2019). In addition, CNTs also have strong adsorption properties, which can remove some pollutants from water. Some scholars used FTIR spectroscopy to study the functional groups generated on the surface of CNTs. The effects of CNTs preparation temperature on FTIR spectra were analyzed. It was found that functionalized CNTs can adsorb some heavy metals and remove some
organic dyes from water (Bahgat et al., 2011). Different methods (fluorination, cycloaddition, reaction with diazonium salt, oxidation and free radical polymerization) can be used to increase the solubility and reactivity of CNTs (Lee et al., 2018). In recent years, many scientists are exploring the application of CNTs in water remediation. Studies have shown that the new MWCNTs prepared by microwave heating can remove Zn(II) from aqueous solution, and the removal rate can reach more than 99% (Mubarak et al., 2015). In addition, there are some reports on the degradation of toxic pollutants in water by CNTs. For example, some scholars have found that both water and phenolic molecules are weakly bound to the outer surface of the original CNTs (weak physical adsorption), and they can be more strongly adsorbed on the functionalized CNTs. It was found that the binding of phenol to CNT-OH was stronger than that of water molecules due to the simultaneous presence of π-π stacking and H-bonding in the system (Moradi et al., 2018). In addition, there are composite materials for the synthesis of CNTs and other substances, which are used to remove pollutants from water. For example, studies have shown that the fast adsorption kinetics are observed, and the 65–85% of BrO3−by Fe-CNTs nanocomposites was adsorbed at different concentrations within 5min. Anchored Fe ions on the nanocomposites surface/in the walls could be important to BrO3− adsorption without leading to structural defects to CNTs (Alsohaimi et al., 2015).

sections.heading: 2.6. Fe3O4 NPs
sections.text: In recent years, magnetic Fe3O4 NPs have been widely studied due to their unique physical and chemical properties (such as quantum size effect, electrical properties and magnetic properties), and have applications in many fields (such as environment and energy). In addition, Fe3O4 NPs can also remove metal ions and organic pollutants from water. For example, Some scholars conducted adsorption experiments on metronidazole (MNZ) using Fe3O4 NPs through the heterogeneous electro-Fenton process, and found that under certain conditions, the maximum removal rate was 92.26% (Rahmatinia and Rahmatinia, 2018). In addition, there are reports on the effect of Fe3O4 NPs on the decolorization of rhodamine B (RhB). The experimental results show that when the amount of Fe3O4 NPs is only 1 g/L, the decolorization rate of RhB is 94.0% and the mineralization rate is 33.6% within 20min (Guo and Jin, 2018). The rifampicin (RIF) removal experiment was carried out by studying the Fe3O4 NPs extracted by Excoecaria cohinchinensis. It was found that at a temperature of 303 K, 10mg of Fe3O4 NPs had an absorption rate of 98.4% and a maximum absorption capacity of 84.8mg/g for the RIF of 20mL. The mechanism of RIF removal by Fe3O4 NPs is adsorption, not chemical redox reaction. It can be seen that the Fe3O4 NPs can remove some pollutants in the water, mainly due to adsorption.

sections.heading: 2.7. Ag NPs
sections.text:
Due to good electrical conductivity, Ag NPs play an extremely important role in the microelectronics field. The surface effects and quantum size effects of Ag NPs also have some special applications, such as surface-enhanced Raman applications and medical applications. Ag NPs can also be used to remove heavy metal contaminants from water. For example, some scholars used activated alumina as a carrier to study the removal rate of mercury ions by Ag NPs under the protection of mercaptosuccinic acid (MSA). The experimental results show that under the condition of 1:6 Ag@MSA, 0.8 g of Hg2+ can be removed by per gram of Ag@MSA, and the adsorption of Hg2+ by the two materials is best at pH 5–6 (Sumesh et al., 2011). Since Ag has a high affinity for iodine, the Ag NPs is fixed on the cellulose acetate membrane to effectively remove radioactive iodine. At a water flow rate of 1.5 mL/s, Ag-CAM can filter out excess 99% of radioactive iodine (Shim et al., 2018). In addition, there is also the inclusion of Ag NPs in activated carbon, which can effectively remove methylene blue. The best
conditions for removing methylene blue from AgNPs-AC are pH 10, contact time 120min, and adsorbent dosage 250 mg/25mL. Under certain conditions, the maximum adsorption capacity of AgNPs-AC for methylene blue was 172.22mg/mL (Van et al., 2018). It can be seen that the removal of pollutants from water by Ag NPs is mainly attributed to adsorption.

sections.heading: 2.8. Others
sections.text: Due to the current serious water crisis, it is urgent to explore advanced water treatment technology in the field of water environment management to provide safe water supply for human activities in an energy-saving and environmental-friendly way. Nanocomposite can partly meet the needs of today's water environment treatment field. For example, semiconductor multiphase photocatalytic nanomaterials have been one of the most effective technologies for water purification (Li and Zhang, 2009). Graphene-nZVI (G-nZVI) can purify disinfection byproducts, especially halogen nitromethane (HNMs), from drinking water. When the mass ratio of iron to carbon is 1:5 in this material, GnZVI shows the best removal efficiency of HNMs (Chen et al., 2016a). The synthesis process of G-nZVI is simple and G-nZVI can easily remove HNMs with excellent performance, which thus becomes an important method for drinking water treatment. Removing Pb(II) ions in aqueous solution has always been the direction of environmental research. It was found that SiO2@OPW had the strongest ability to remove Pb from water. A study (Wang et al., 2018a) was designed to explore the mesoporous magnetism of Fe/C nanomaterials, in which carbon nanomaterial greatly enhanced the adsorption of organic dye in the water. A new type of 0D/2D composite nanomembrane has been developed based on the membrane assembled by nanomaterials (Wang et al., 2018b). It is a major breakthrough in the separation field that the composite nanomembrane has high stability after running for 40 h in a water environment. Another study also attempted to modify the nanostructure of a CNT-rGO composite membrane and found that it is feasible to achieve high cleaning membrane permeability, excellent antifouling performance and efficient pollutant removal rate (Wang et al., 2018c). The active TiO2 embedded in polymethyl methacrylate obviates the need to recycle the nanoparticles of this material after water treatment, and as a highly efficient photocatalytic and antibacterial composite nanomaterial it successfully overcomes the problem of nanomaterial dispersion in water (Cantarella et al., 2016). To sum up, nanocomposites are a promising material for water environment treatment.

sections.heading: 3. Toxic effect and mechanism of nanomaterials in water environment
sections.text:
Nanomaterials have been increasingly and widely applied in many fields, such as ecology, medicine, fashion, cosmetics, materials science, and so on (Jiang et al., 2018; Schirinzi et al., 2017). However, the use of nanomaterials also brings some harmful effects to ecology and environment (Adam et al., 2018; Chen et al., 2017; Vinković et al., 2017; Voelker et al., 2015). Some of the nanomaterials are inevitably released into rivers, lakes and seas. Drinking water can eventually be affected by these materials as well. Therefore, contamination of water environments caused by these materials may be harmful to aquatic life or human beings.
Different types of nanomaterials or even the same kind of nanomaterials at different sizes were found to have an inconsistently toxic effect on some organisms. The toxicity and function of common nanomaterials are shown in Table 2.

sections.heading: 3.1. Toxic effect on plankton
sections.text:
Nanomaterials may produce toxic effects on a part of planktons. Thus, the impacts of some nanomaterials such as Ag NPs, TiO2 NPs and
nZVI on plankton have been assessed. It was found that, compared with ordinary polyethylene, Ag NPs have good mildew resistance as well as physical and chemical properties (Li et al., 2017). However, excessive use of Ag NPs could have a negative impact. With the increase of time, Ag NPs clearly inhibited the activity of ammonia-oxidizing bacteria (Schlich et al., 2018). Besides Ag NPs, TiO2 NPs are white loose rutile powders with strong UV shielding, good dispersion and strong weather resistance. With the increase of the concentration of TiO2 NPs, the effects on plant growth are mainly reflected in the changes in relative found number (RFN), leaf size, photosynthetic pigment content, active peroxidase (POD) and other growth parameters (Movafeghi et al., 2018).
Even exposed to low concentrations of CuO NPs, fronds per colony of Lemna minor decrease and the root growth rate is also gradually reduced (Dolenc Koce, 2017). Once Cu NPs appear in water, they can dissolve with other particles and form insoluble compounds. Different Cu NPs have different effects on plankton, and they have serious or minor effects on the enzyme activity of plankton (Hou et al., 2017). In particular, different tissues and organs from the same plankton are subjected to different levels of toxicity (Khosravi−Katuli et al., 2018). Also, high concentrations of ZnO NPs may inhibit the growth of rice seedlings (Singh et al., 2018). Low concentrations of nZVI promoted rice growth, but nZVI at high concentrations caused damage to plant cells (Guha et al., 2018). In general, low concentrations of nanoparticles have no harmful effect on planktons. As the concentration increases, the growth of planktons will be disturbed or inhibited. However, some nanoparticles, such as CuO NPs, can slow the growth of plankton even at the lowest measured concentrations (Koce, 2017).

sections.heading: 3.2. Toxic effect on microbes
sections.text:
There are a large number of microbes presented in water environments. Thus, it will be a common event for nanomaterials to interact with the microbes after they enter the water environments. Here, the effects of some nanomaterials such as CNTs, GO, nZVI, Ag NPs, ZnO NPs and CuO NPs on microbes are summarized.
CNTs alter the oxidation behavior of enzymes in water molecules, which produce toxicity to microorganisms (Chen et al., 2016b). GO increases the active oxygen concentration, but it does not damage cells. When high concentrations of Ag NPs were added, the enzyme activity was reduced, but the genes for defense mechanisms were increased (Li et al., 2019c). When nZVI is in direct contact with bacteria cells, it causes oxidative stress and membrane destruction. This results in the loss of intracellular material and the disruption of communication between the outside world and bacteria cells (Lv et al., 2017). For worms exposed to high levels of nZVI, the rate of reproduction declined rapidly (Liang et al., 2018). Sekar et al. tested the optimum concentration of CleZnO NPs on bacterial cells, and no mortality was noticed in Daphnia longicephala under the condition with bare zinc acetate, collagen and CleZnO NPs of 250 μg/mL (Vijayakumar and Vaseeharan, 2018). The effect of Ag NPs and ZnO NPs on the performance of bacteria lies in the size of the particles, and the microbial population decreases as the concentration increases (Mboyi et al., 2017). When ZnO NPs are involved in anaerobic fermentation, free zinc ions are absorbed in the sludge, resulting in the decrease in zinc ion concentration, key enzyme activity, cell activity, and bacterial abundance (Zhang et al., 2018). According to the HTS growth inhibition experiment of Escherichia coli cultured in minimal medium, the toxicity of Cu NPs is higher than that of micro Cu, nano CuO, micro CuO and two forms of Cu(OH)2 (nCu (OH)2-a and nCu(OH)2-b) (Keller et al., 2017). In general, the toxicity mechanism of nanomaterials on microbes mainly involves oxidative stress, membrane destruction, etc (Chen et al., 2019).
In summary, plankton (e.g., Lemna minor, diatom, cyanobacteria, otter, and artemia) and microbes (e.g., Escherichia coli, Bacillus subtilis, Serratia. marcescens, Bacillus cereus, and Staphylococcus epidermidis) in the water environment are more susceptible to the toxicity of
nanomaterials. Moreover, these aquatic organisms are affected by the toxicity of nanomaterials and sometimes are difficult to recover due to that nanomaterials can not only cause cell damage, but also damage genes and affect reproduction.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text: So far, great progress has been made in the study of nanomaterials in water environments. We thus focused on this topic in this review article by summarizing the behavior, remediation effect and toxicity of nanomaterials in water environments. Different nanomaterials exhibit distinct behavior in a variety of water environments, where they can affect each other. Some nanomaterials have good adsorption capacity for heavy metals and organic pollutants. Also, nanomaterials can be used as adsorbents, catalysts and membrane materials for water purification. In lakes, rivers, oceans or wetlands, the application of nanotechnology to water pollution control presents a booming scene. However, some nanomaterials often have toxic effects on aquatic organisms when they are at high concentrations. For example, nanomaterials can produce oxidative stress in fleas, leading to membrane destruction and death of cells due to the loss of necessary life functions. Nanomaterials at certain concentrations can reduce the growth and reproduction rate of plants, and they reduce the photosynthetic efficiency of plant cells and alter the content of plant pigments. However, nanomaterials can have positive effects at low concentrations, such as promoting plant growth. Up to now, the relationship between nanomaterials and water environment remains unclear and warrants further studies. Some questions, (e.g., What are the reasons that cause differences in behavior of nanomaterials? What causes the different remediation effect and toxicity of nanomaterials to organisms in different water environments? Are there more nanomaterials available for water purification and remediation?) need to be explored.

metadata.abstractText: In recent years, nanotechnology has been developing continuously. Due to their advantageous huge specific surface areas, microinterface characteristics, remediation ability and potential environmental risks, nanomaterials have become a hot topic in the field of environmental research. With the mass production and use of nanomaterials, they will inevitably be discharged or leaked into the water environment. In this paper, we will describe some typical nanomaterials, such as nanoscale zero valent iron (nZVI), graphene nanomaterials (GNMs), TiO2 nanoparticles (NPs), ZnO NPs, Fe3O4 NPs, carbon nanotubes (CNTs), Ag NPs, and other nanomaterials in water environments, focusing on the positive and negative effects of some nanomaterials in water environments. The remediation function and the impact of nanomaterials in water environments, including behavior of nanomaterials and their toxicity to aquatic organisms will be discussed. This will be of great significance for our subsequent research on nanomaterials. 1. Environmental behavior of nanomaterials in water environment Currently, most scientists believe that nanomaterials are one of the mainstays of developing science and technology in the 21st century. A growing number of nanomaterials can enter the environment (Adam and Nowack, 2017; Caballero-Guzman and Nowack, 2016), especially the water environment, through different pathways. Therefore, the relationship between nanomaterials and water environments has become a hot topic worldwide. The behavior of nanomaterials in various water environments including lake, river, ocean, and wetlands has been investigated in the past years. Next we will elaborate the relationship between nanomaterials and water environment (Fig. 1). In the lake environment, nanomaterials can affect microbial activity and growth. Simultaneously, the properties and behavior of nanomaterials may be influenced by lakes. For example, the stability of Ag NPs coated with polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP), citrate (CIT), or lipoic acid (LIP) at different sizes in lake water was examined, and results showed that AgNPs stability was determined by dissolved organic matter (DOM), exposure time and the surface coating characteristics (Jimenez−Lamana and Slaveykova, 2016). The study further found that surface coating was a key factor governing the behavior of AgNPs in lake water. The impact of titanium nanoparticles (TiO2 NPs) on freshwater bacteria in three Swedish lakes was studied (Farkas et al., 2015), and the authors found that TiO2 NPs could inhibit the proliferation and activity of bacteria in the lakes. The increase of nanomaterials in rivers comes from various potential artificial channels, such as nanotechnology waste, oil refinery, automobile traffic, life drain, vessel, etc. For instance, environmental concentrations of fullerenes and their derivatives in Sava River have been determined (Sanchís et al., 2018). C60 was found to be the most common fullerene. If its concentration is in the range of 8 pg/L-59 ng/L in water, C60 will not cause significant toxicity in water environments. However, the concentrations reported were apparently higher than normal concentrations found in surface water. The key for the increase in content of C60 and its derivatives is that we should pay attention to hydrological conditions.
